context: <a4_0>Around the beginning of the 20th century<a4_0/>, <a0_0>William James<a0_0/> (<a2_0>1842<a2_0/>–<a3_0>1910<a3_0/>) coined the term "radical empiricism" to describe an offshoot of his form of pragmatism, which he argued could be dealt with separately from his pragmatism – though in fact the two concepts are intertwined <a1_0>in <b7_0>James's published lectures<b7_0/><a1_0/>. James maintained that <b8_0>the empirically observed "directly apprehended universe needs ... no extraneous trans-empirical connective support"<b8_0/>, by which he meant to rule out the perception that there can be any value added by seeking supernatural explanations for natural phenomena. James's "<b6_0>radical empiricism<b6_0/>" is thus not radical in the context of the term "empiricism", <b5_0>but is instead fairly consistent with the modern use of the term "empirical"<b5_0/>. (His method of argument in arriving at this view, however, still readily encounters debate within philosophy even today.)
